awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Advanced Li-S Battery System for Unmanned Air Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) project includes reducing the US dependence on foreign-sourced materials for the production and supply of battery systems. There are increased concerns about the shortage of materials for lithium ion batteries (LIB) as the number of electric vehicles increases.  Lithium Sulfur (Li-S) batteries use sulfur which is more readily available, lower cost, and environment-friendly. Li-S batteries do not require the use of sulfuric acid or other more harmful chemicals, which allows them to be disposed of easily or recycled. This project will advance knowledge in addressing challenges to the development of practical and commercially viable (Li-S) batteries. The Global Lithium-Sulfur (Li-S) Battery Market was valued at $696 Million in 2019 and is anticipated to reach $6,686 Million by 2028, with a CAGR of 29.6% during the forecast period. Li-S batteries are mainly used in aviation, automotive, electronic device, and power & energy sector due to the growing demand for environmentally friendly energy with higher energy density than other battery types. Li-S technology has potential to enhance safer battery manufacturing in the US.


This STTR Phase II project proposes to address important technical challenges against the development of practical Li-S batteries. These challenges include limited cycle life, high self-discharge rates and over-heating at end of charge. These are thought to be caused by the shuttle, where cathode species diffuse to the anode and react directly with the metallic lithium. A system approach will be employed to develop practical high performance Li-S Cells by focusing on: Performance (high energy density, large temperature range, and considerable cycle life); safety; and manufacturability. The project combines experimental and electrochemical modeling approaches to achieve a Li-S cell with 400-600 Wh/kg; ≥200 cycles; - 20oC to 60oC @ 1C. The project will use advanced trilayer multifunctional separator and lithium metal anode to solve the problems associated with the shuttling effect. Simulation tools will be used to study and optimize the design and performance of the Li-S cells. The technical objectives for Phase 2 include the design, fabrication and characterization of progressively larger pouch cells (from 50 mAh to 500 mAh/1000 mAh). The development path will focus on achieving high energy density Li-S cells first and increasing the temperature range at a reasonable number of cycles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Despite the challenges imposed by the Covid-19 Pandemic, our team made progress both in the technical area and on the business side. Working on this project with the support of the NSF has enabled Valgotech LLC to develop the critical expertise and partnerships needed for the successful development and commercialization of Li-S batteries. The team not only developed technical expertise, but we have also identified viable technology path that will enable us to reach the 350 – 400 Wh/kg specific energy density goal. The current approach employed in the project used the elemental S as the cathode. Our work showed that the maximum practically obtainable specific energy density limit is about 200 Wh/kg. We achieved a specific energy density of 180 Wh/kg in pouch cells.

During this project, we fabricated and tested multiple pouch cells ranging in capacity from 80 – 1400 mAh. Working with pouch cells, and not just coin cells, provided key insights for the operation of Li-S cells under lean electrolyte conditions that are critical for high energy density Li-S cells that are commercially viable. We were able to reduce the electrolyte to sulfur (E/S) ratio from 20 to 4.5 µl/mg while increasing the sulfur loading to as high as 3.5 mg/cm2. Reducing the E/S ratio and increasing the S loading are critical to achieving high energy density. We developed a 1.45Ah pouch cell, with optimized sulfur loading and electrolyte/sulfur ratio, which delivers an energy density of 151 Wh/kg with 70% capacity retention up to 100 cycles. Targeting higher energy density (180 Wh/kg), our 1Ah pouch cell exhibits 68% capacity retention after 50 cycles. The limited cycle life shows the effect of polysulfide shuttling which our team will be addressing as we proceed with our Li-S battery technology development.

In addition, we successfully incorporated our Li-S batteries into a mini drone to power it. The prototype demonstration shows that assembled pouch cells with optimized S-loading and electrolyte ratio are particularly suitable for different applications such as drones, electric vertical take-off vehicles (eVTOL), electric vehicles (EVs), hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), and grid energy storage. In going forward, we will be pursuing the SPAN cathode technology as this pathway will enable us to reach the target the 350 – 400 Wh/kg specific energy density goal. We will also be addressing the polysulfide shuttling effect so as to enable a battery with longer cycle life.

We also developed and filed a patent for a solvent-free electrode and solid-state electrolyte manufacturing process that is 15 times faster than the conventional wet process. The Valgotech proprietary process eliminates the use of toxic and expensive solvents like the NMP in the electrode manufacturing process. Valgotech’s proprietary dry battery electrode process technology will help to reduce US dependence on foreign-sourced cells and cathode materials, as well as jumpstart low-cost cell manufacturing in the US.

On the commercial side, Valgotech was successful with the Air Force AFWERX phase 1 ($75,000) and successfully submitted an Air Force Phase 2 SBIR that required getting a customer memorandum from Air Force customer and end-user. The company also participated in multiple accelerators including the Gener8tor Energy and Sustainability Accelerator and the Mass Challenge (DoD) focused. The company also secured investment and grant from Elevate Ventures.

At Valgotech, the project resulted in energy storage technical and business exposures to one undergraduate intern, two master’s degree holders, and two doctorate degree holders. At Purdue University, a postdoc, one doctoral student and a couple of master’s students were involved with the project. These exposures are helping to develop the manpower and expertise required to regain the United States leadership role in energy storage development and manufacturing. Valgotech will continue to focus on its Li-S battery technology development with particular emphasis on achieving high energy density, longer cycle life, and superior SPA (safety, performance, and affordability).

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2024
Modified by: Md Sajibul Alam   Bhuyan
